Laboratory of Separation and Reaction Engineering - Laboratory of Catalysis and Materials (LSRE-LCM), Faculdade de Engenharia, Universidade do Porto Rua Dr. Roberto Frias Porto 4200-465 Portugal The development of macrostructured catalysts for remediation processes is a key step towards the sustainability of multi-phase environmental systems, such as the catalytic reduction of inorganic contaminants. The advances towards practical applications faces great challenges regarding the availability of active centers on catalysts surface. To improve the catalytic activity of macrostructured bimetallic catalysts, it is crucial to understand which are the properties that most influence the catalytic activity of materials deposited on macrostructured supports. This work presents a systematic study on the design of macrostructured bimetallic catalysts with enhanced catalytic activity and selectivity. These materials were tested for selective NO3 - conversion to N2. The adoption of different synthesis methodologies allowed a higher metal-metal interaction, which is an important property influencing the efficiency of the bimetallic catalyst. Metal phase distribution through coating layers proved to be a key-step for the synthesis of more active and N2 selective structured catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Macrostructured catalysts Metal-alloy Metal distribution Denitrification N2 selectivity 1 Introduction Nitrate (NO3 -) contamination is strongly associated with the use of fertilizers and the disposal of industrial/agricultural effluents where large amounts of nitrogen compounds are commonly present [1]. The ingestion of water contaminated with NO3 - is harmful due to the possible formation of NO2 - in the organism that can cause blue baby syndrome and it is, also, a precursor to the carcinogenic nitrous amine [2,3]. The European and US legislation have established drinking water maximum concentrations of 50, 0.1 and 0.5 mg L−1 for NO3 -, NO2 - and NH4 +, respectively [4]. The World Health Organization recommends tighter limits, namely 10, 0.03 and 0.4 mg L−1 [5]. Thus, the increasing pollution of natural drinking water sources encourages the development of innovative technologies for water remediation in what concerns to NO3 - conversion [6]. Among the different techniques that have been developed over the past few years, heterogeneous catalytic reduction emerges as an efficient and sustainable mechanism to perform the conversion of NO3 - into less toxic species (namely N2) [7]. The most significant advantage associated with this technology is related to the possibility of converting NO3 - in less toxic species while avoiding the trapping of the main pollutant as it happens in the most common techniques applied for the removal of this type of species (namely in ion exchange or membrane separation) [8,9]. This conversion can already be achieved through biological denitrification; however, the process is still very slow, requiring very large infrastructures and multistage processes in order to achieve good results in NO3 - conversion and N2 selectivity [10,11]. Briefly, catalytic reduction of NO3 - occurs in the presence of a reducing agent and over a bimetallic catalyst, composed by a noble and a promoter metal, where NO3 - hydrogenation leads to the formation of nitrite (NO2 -), as an intermediate compound, and to N2 and NH4 + as final products, with the latter being the reaction undesirable by-product [7,12]. Over the past few years, several studies have been reported focusing on the application of different bimetallic combinations for the synthesis of active and stable catalysts that would promote NO3 - catalytic reduction with high selectivity to N2 [13–19]. Among all the combinations, palladium-copper emerged as an interesting bimetallic combination to achieve a good compromise between a NO3 - conversion and the minimization of NH4 + formation [3,7,20–22]. Several studies reported that the use of an adequate support played a key role in the conversion and selectivity achieved during reaction, beyond that of merely a carrier for the metallic phase of the catalyst [23–25]. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were identified as a promising support for the metallic phase due to their inherent properties associated with the surface chemistry and textural properties of the material [25–28]. Additionally, Soares et al. [26] reported that the possibility of performing mechano-chemical modifications on the CNTs structure (such as milling and/or introducing different heteroatoms in their structure) allowed these materials to be used as supports for metal nanoparticles with improved results for BrO3 - conversion. Mainly, the milling process showed significant advantages in enhancing the catalyst activity since it is often associated with an increase in the specific surface area of the CNTs. However, most of these studies focus on the development of this type of catalyst in powder form (being the only way to take advantage of the catalytic properties of mechano-chemical modified catalysts), which can present severe limitations when the final objective is the application in a continuous operating system. The major difficulties of this application are associated with high-pressure drop and flow maldistribution (when used in a fixed bed). Furthermore, there are environmental concerns with the application of powder nanomaterials in water treatment as it may represent a considerable danger to human health and aquatic species, so an additional filtration step, to ensure the recovery of all the catalysts, is necessary [29–31]. To overcome these disadvantages, the immobilization of powder catalysts in macrostructured supports, such as honeycomb cordierite monoliths, emerges as an efficient solution to the application of this type of catalysts in continuous heterogeneous catalytic reactions for water treatment [32–34]. The most common procedure to perform this immobilization consists in the in situ growth of carbon nanofibers or nanotubes on a cordierite macro-structure through chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [35,36]; however, such approach is incompatible with the advances in the mechano-chemical modification of CNTs, that do not apply to in-situ grown materials, and that are responsible to significantly increase the catalytic performance of the catalysts [37]. An alternative method consists of applying a conventional washcoating technique to incorporate pre-modified powder catalysts allowing to take advantage of all the modifications that can be performed on the powder form. The use of organic solvents for the formation of the coating slurry can be avoided by ensuring proper dispersion of the hydrophobic carbon nanotubes with the aid of an organic binder in water [37–39]. This technique allows the incorporation of modified powder catalysts on the structured support to take advantage of the properties achieved by the powder form modifications even if incorporated in the macrostructured support. Moreover, this technique emerges as an interesting alternative to perform the incorporation of powder metallic materials through a one-step immobilization procedure, as opposed to the hard to implement and scale-up CVD processes. The present work aims to assess different metal impregnation strategies on the formation of bimetallic CNT-coated macrostructured catalysts using pre- or post-coating impregnation approaches, in particular focusing on the availability of active sites for reaction, the interaction between the noble and promotor metal, and the impact of the catalyst properties on its activity and selectivity. Different approaches were studied in order to synthesize stable and active palladium-copper bimetallic catalysts on nanocarbon supports: i) the adsorption of the metal phase on a previously carbon coated support (synthesized through CVD or washcoating) and ii) washcoating of the pre-formed bimetallic catalysts directly on the cordierite macrostructure. All the catalysts were tested in a continuous operating system for nitrate reduction using optimized gas and liquid flow conditions previously determined. The synthesis procedure was optimized in order to design stable and active bimetallic macrostructured catalysts for application in a continuous catalytic reduction process. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalysts preparation The methods used in the catalysts preparation are described for both the powder and structured CNT-based catalysts. 2.1.1 Powder materials Bimetallic powder catalysts with 5 % Pd-2.5 % Cu (in weight) were synthesized through incipient wetness co-impregnation using an aqueous solution of the corresponding metal salts (PdCl2 and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O) on the selected supports. Commercial multi-walled carbon nanotubes (CNT) from Nanocyl (Nanocyl 3100) were used as the main support for the metallic phase. Modification of the as-received CNT was carried out by ball-milling in a Retsch MM200 equipment using a frequency of 15 vibrations/s during 2 h (CNT(BM 2 h)). After impregnation, the samples were dried at 100 °C overnight, followed by a reductive thermal treatment at 200 °C (1 h under N2 flow and 3 h under H2 flow) to reduce the metal phase of the catalyst and for highly-dispersed metallic nanoparticles [25,28]. 2.1.2 Structured catalysts Bimetallic macrostructured catalysts, supported on ceramic cordierite honeycomb monoliths from Corning (1 cm diameter, 6 cm length and with 100 channels per square inch), were synthesized through two different methodologies. The following section describes these techniques: the first was used to achieve the incorporation of Pd and Cu on previously carbon coated cordierite macrostructures (described in Section 2.1.2.1); the second was used to achieve the direct incorporation of the pre-formed bimetallic catalyst (5 % Pd-2.5 % Cu/CNT(BM 2 h)) directly on the cordierite macrostructures (described in Section 2.1.2.2). All the macrostructured cordierite supports were calcined at 900 °C under air, before any further processing, to remove any impurities that could be present on the support [40]. 2.1.2.1 Bimetallic macrostructured catalysts synthesized through Pd-Cu adsorption on the carbon coated structure The synthesis of the supported bimetallic catalysts was carried out on cordierite macro-structures previously coated with CNT. Two different methodologies were considered to achieve a well adhered carbon coating of the macrostructured support with carbon: chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and washcoating procedure (WCP). These techniques have been extensively described in previous works [36,37,41]. Briefly, for the CVD technique, monoliths were sequentially dipped into a colloidal alumina suspension and a nickel solution, with a thermal treatment at 450 °C under N2 (50 cm3/min) between each stage. The growth of the carbon nanofibers on the monolithic structure was achieved by reaction of a C2H6:H2 mixture (30:30 v/v) at 650 °C. WCP consists of the incorporation of the ball-milled CNT (CNT(BM 2 h)) powder material, properly dispersed in ultra-pure water with the aid of a surfactant (Triton X-100™ (TX100) from Sigma-Aldrich), through dip-coating using a Bungard RDC21 K coater. The monolith coating was performed 5 times with a drying step in an oven (at 100 °C) between each coating. Finally, the monolith was calcined during 1 h, under N2 atmosphere, at 550 °C to ensure the complete decomposition of the surfactant. The washcoating methodology used during the present work have been previously optimized in order to select the mass of catalyst incorporated on the structured support [37]. Adsorption of the metallic phase was performed through the direct contact of the CNT coated macrostructured supports with aqueous solutions (5 % HCl) of the respective metals precursors (PdCl2 and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O). The main goal was to obtain macrostructured catalysts with metals loadings close to those studied for the powder catalysts (5 % Pd and 2.5 % Cu). The loading of each metal to be incorporated was calculated taking into account the mass of carbon on the structure. The CNT coated monoliths were placed in contact with the metal solution(s) in a shaking water bath (VWR) during 8 h, in order to promote the flowing of the liquid through the monoliths channels and the metal species adsorption on the carbon layers. Afterwards, the macro-structured catalysts were dried and a reductive thermal treatment, similar to the one applied to the powder catalysts (200 °C, 1 h N2 and 3 h H2), was performed in order to obtain a fine dispersion of metallic nanoparticles (samples WCP_550_[PdCu] and CVD_[PdCu]). The schematic representation of the adopted general procedure can be found in the Supplementary information (Fig. S1). A staged adsorption approach was also studied to gain insight into the metal uptake and incorporation during adsorption and its influence on the catalysts’ properties and consequently their performance. This procedure consisted of the deposition of the two metals separately (first palladium and then copper) with and without performing reductive thermal treatment between each stage (samples WCP_550_Pd_Cu, WCP_550_Pd_200_Cu and CVD_Pd_200_Cu). The schematic representation of these procedures can be found in the Supplementary information (Fig. S1). 2.1.2.2 Bimetallic macrostructured catalysts synthesized through the incorporation of the pre-formed Pd-Cu/CNT catalyst directly on cordierite macrostructures The direct incorporation of the pre-formed bimetallic powder material was achieved through washcoating. The adopted methodology was similar to the one described in Section 2.1.2.1 to prepare the WCP CNT-coated structured supports using, instead, 5 % Pd-2.5 % Cu/CNT(BM 2 h) bimetallic catalyst. For these catalysts, the removal of the TX100 surfactant was optimized as the application of high temperatures (550 °C to achieve total TX100 degradation) will lead to sintering of the metal nanoparticles [37,42]. A systematic study was carried out to understand the effect of different approaches for TX100 removal: on one hand, after the coating, a calcination thermal treatment, at 350 or 550 °C was carried out in order to perform TX100 degradation (samples [PdCu]/WCP_350 and [PdCu]/WCP_550) [43,44]; otherwise, a washing procedure using a solution of isopropanol and acetone (IPA:ACN) (1:1 v/v) was also tested (sample [PdCu]/WCP_wash) without recourse to high temperature thermal treatments [45]. The schematic representation of the followed methodology for the synthesis of bimetallic macrostructured catalysts through washcoating can be found in Fig. S2 on Supplementary information. Table 1 briefly summarizes all the prepared and tested samples. 2.2 Characterization techniques Characterization of the prepared catalysts was performed to compare the techniques used to synthesize the bimetallic macrostructured catalysts. The powder materials used during the present work have been extensively characterized in previous works [28,46]. ICP-OES analyses were performed in order to quantify the amounts of Pd and Cu present on the synthesized macrostructured catalysts. These experiments were carried out in an ICP–OES ICAP 7400 THERMO equipped with a nebulizing system and using optical emission spectroscopy for detection. For this quantification, all samples were subjected to a digestion process before analysis. The samples digestion was performed in a Milestone START D microwave digester. Hydrogen chemisorption experiments were performed on the macrostructured bimetallic catalysts. The main objective of these analyzes was to assess the formation of metal alloys on the macrostructured catalysts by comparing hydrogen chemisorption on monometallic palladium and bimetallic palladium-copper catalysts prepared under the same conditions. Hydrogen is chemisorbed only on Pd ensembles and the difference in the volume of hydrogen uptakes between mono and bimetallic samples were related to alloy formation or covering of Pd active sites [47]. These experiments were performed in an Altamira AMI-200 apparatus. For these analyzes, the samples were reduced at 200 °C under H2 and kept under an inert atmosphere during cooling down to 35 °C, when repeated pulses of H2 were injected in a carrier gas (25 cm3/min of Ar), and flown over the sample until saturation of the metal with chemisorbed hydrogen. The adsorbed hydrogen quantity was measured using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Temperature programmed reduction analyses were performed in the same equipment for selected powder samples. Samples were heated until around 1000 °C (5 °C min−1) under a flow of 1.5 cm3 min−1 of H2 diluted in 29 cm3 min−1 of He. H2 consumption during analysis was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). To obtain information regarding the macrostructured catalyst structure, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analyses were performed using a transmission electron microscope with high-contrast JEOL JEM-1010 100 kV. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with coupled EDS (Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy) detector (SEM/EDS) was used to image the samples at a FEI QUANTA 400 FEG ESEM/EDAX PEGASUS X4M microscope. Through this technique, a mapping of the macrostructured catalyst was performed in order to obtain representative images of the distribution of the metallic phases along with the different coating layers. X-ray diffraction analyses (XRD) were performed for selected powder catalysts in order to understand the influence of the presence of two metals on the catalyst surface and understand the interaction between them (possible formation of metallic alloys). These experiments were performed with a PANalytical X′Pert PRO diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation source (λ = 1.54 nm). 2.3 Continuous nitrate reduction catalytic experiments Catalytic nitrate reduction experiments were performed in a continuous operating custom-made experimental set-up consisting of a bubble column with an internal recirculation loop. A schematic representation of the experimental reactor is present in Supplementary information (Fig. S3). For these experiments, 30 mg L−1 nitrate solution (prepared in distilled water) was introduced at the top of the column using a peristaltic pump at 10 cm3 min−1. H2, used as reducing agent, and CO2 as pH buffer (pH value of 5.5 to help avoid NH4 + formation, H2 + CO2 (1:1), Q Total = 200 N cm3 min−1) were introduced at the bottom of the column, allowing to create a counter-current system. The residence time distribution (RTD) of this custom designed system was previously determined, and an average residence time of 20 min was obtained [43]. The chosen NO3 - concentration was selected based on former studies to be representative of nitrate formation during the degradation of a nitrogenated model organic compound through an ozonation process [28,46,48]. The reaction conditions used during the present work were stipulated taking into account some optimization experiments performed for the continuous catalytic reactor. Samples were collected at specific times, from the reactor outlet, to quantify NO3 -, NH4 + and NO2 - concentrations. This quantification was performed by ionic chromatography in a Metrohm 881 Compact IC Pro apparatus, equipped with a Metrosep A Supp 7 Anionic Exchange Column (250 mm × 4.0 mm) for anionic species quantification and Metrosep C4 Cationic Exchange Column (250 mm × 4.0 mm) for cationic species analysis. NO3 - conversion and NO2 -, NH4 + and N2 selectivities were calculated as described in [49]. The obtained results correspond to an average of five points taken at fixed intervals (30 min) along the reaction after the stationary state was reached. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The bimetallic powder catalyst selected for this study (5 % Pd-2.5 % Cu/CNT(BM 2 h)) was extensively characterized in previous works [28,48]. Briefly, specific surface area (SBET) values reported for the bimetallic catalyst (5 % Pd-2.5 % Cu/CNT(BM 2 h)) was 203 m2/g, indicating a slight decrease in the specific surface area after impregnation of the metallic phase on the carbon support (SBET of 220 m2/g). TEM images showed that the material presents a good metal dispersion on the carbon support with an average metal particle size around 5–7 nm [28]. Standard adherence experiments were performed for the macrostructured catalysts by applying an ultrasonic treatment for 30 min to evaluate the coating adherence to the cordierite structure; the obtained results showed that the coating layer was resistant and remained well adhered to the support, proving the good stability of the catalyst. Selected macrostructured catalysts were analyzed by TEM ( Fig. 1) to obtain information related to the morphological structure of these materials. The histograms representative of the metal particle size distribution for each catalyst are present in Supplementary information (Fig. S3). TEM micrographs corresponding to the macrostructured bimetallic catalysts synthesized through adsorption of the metallic phase (Fig. 1 (A)–(D)) allow identification of a large quantity of well-dispersed metallic nanoparticles deposited on the carbon coating. Fig. 1 (C) and (D) correspond to the bimetallic macrostructured catalysts synthesized through a staged adsorption process (WCP_550_Pd_200_Cu and CVD_Pd_200_Cu, respectively) and it was not possible to verify significant morphological differences between the two methodologies. However, ICP-OES analyses of the digested macrostructured bimetallic catalysts revealed a large difference in the quantity of metal deposited on the macrostructured catalysts. The results regarding the quantity of each metal present on the carbon structure per total mass of carbon, obtained through ICP-OES, are present in Table 2. The co-adsorption of the two metals on the carbon support (samples WCP_550_[PdCu] and CVD_[PdCu]) leads to a combined metal uptake considerably lower than in the case of the staged adsorption process. For the CVD_[PdCu] percentages, of around 0.6 % of Pd and 0.2 % of Cu, per carbon content, were registered, however, when a staged adsorption procedure was adopted (with a calcination/reduction thermal treatment between the adsorption of each metal) the metal uptake significantly increased to around 0.8 % of Pd and 0.6 % of Cu, per carbon content, showing that this process plays an important role for the increase of metal uptake. The same behavior was registered for WCP_550_Pd-Cu (0.37 % Pd and 0.14 % Cu, per carbon content) and WCP_550_Pd_200_Cu (with a metal 1.63 % Pd and 1.49 % Cu per carbon content) catalysts, however, even presenting less carbon in their structure, these catalysts showed higher loading than the catalysts synthesized through CVD. The carbon content of the macrostructured catalysts achieved with each of the followed methodologies was determined through thermogravimetric analysis as performed in previous studies [37]. The obtained results estimate a carbon content of around 11 % for the CVD synthesized catalysts and around 2 % for the washcoated macrostructured catalysts. Also, previous works proved that CVD catalysts tend to have a less packed CNT layer [32,43]. For the bimetallic macrostructured catalysts synthesized through washcoating procedure of the pre-formed powder catalyst, it is evident that applying a higher thermal treatment temperature (550 °C) leads to metal nanoparticles sintering, as it is possible to observe in Fig. 1 (E). This phenomenon has been previously identified and studied for different metallic catalysts proving to be a factor that strongly affects the efficiency of the catalytic process [42]. For the specific case of Pd-Cu bimetallic catalysts, the ideal calcination/reduction temperature would be 200 °C; however, to ensure a complete degradation of the TX100 surfactant, higher calcination temperatures are necessary (around 550 °C), leading to the formation of higher metallic nanoparticles on the surface of the support [42]. Previous studies have shown that this phenomenon can be avoided by promoting the removal of the surfactant through the exposure to an organic solvent solution (isopropanol and acetone) [41,45]. In the TEM micrograph obtained for [PdCu]/WCP_wash (Fig. 1 (F)), it is possible to identify small metal nanoparticles that are deposited on and inside the carbon nanotubes. This is made evident in higher magnifications micrographs presented in Fig. 2. Typically, the use of a milled support (CNT(BM 2 h)) for the synthesis of the powder bimetallic catalysts (5 %Pd-2.5 %Cu/CNT(BM 2 h)) can lead to a preferential deposition of the metal nanoparticles inside the tubes, as it was previously reported [28]. This happens due to the breaking of the tubes during the milling process, promoting the formation of open endings and allowing the entering of the metals into the tubes during impregnation [50,51]. For these catalysts a metal percentage of 1.6 % of Pd and 0.4 % of Cu, per mass of carbon, were identified on catalysts structure. Hydrogen chemisorption experiments were performed for the synthesized bimetallic and corresponding monometallic structured catalysts to compare the amount of hydrogen chemisorbed in each catalyst ( Table 3). These experiments were performed considering that hydrogen does not chemisorb on copper nanoparticles; therefore, the difference recorded between the monometallic and bimetallic catalyst corresponds to the possible formation of Pd-Cu alloys. However, it is necessary to consider that other factors can also contribute to differences in hydrogen uptake when a second metal is added to the catalyst (such as the rearrangement of Pd nanoparticles). Generally, it is possible to verify that H2 chemisorption decreases for the powder catalysts upon Cu addition. This result is in agreement with previous studies performed with Pd-Cu bimetallic catalysts, in different supports, where the addition of Cu can lead to the direct formation of PdCu bonds leading to a partial Pd coverage, and thus, it not being available to chemisorb H2, as previously mentioned [9,52–54]. This decrease in chemisorption values may also be associated with the formation of alloys by d-band mixing that affects the formation energy associated with the bonding of hydrogen to Pd, causing this energy to be lower and, thus, possibly leading to a decrease in the hydrogen chemisorbed during analysis [55,56]. Through the direct comparison of the values obtained for mono and bimetallic catalysts, it is possible to generally conclude that the adoption of a staged adsorption methodology (WCP_550_Pd_200_Cu and CVD_Pd_200_Cu) leads to a higher formation of Pd-Cu alloys, or promotes a higher proximity of both metals, than the co-adsorption process (WCP_550_[PdCu] and CVD_[PdCu]). The staged adsorption approach has been previously studied in several works related to the synthesis of bimetallic catalyst and a great importance was assigned to the chosen order for metals deposition and how this would influence the formation of metallic alloys and its importance for a more efficient catalytic process [57,58]. For the macrostructured catalysts synthesized through washcoating procedure the amount of chemisorbed H2 decreases for the bimetallic catalyst ([PdCu]/WCP_wash) when compared with its monometallic counterpart. As it was previously described (in the Materials and Methods section), the powder bimetallic catalyst is directly incorporated on the macroscopic structure through the application of a washcoating procedure; thus, the arrangement of the metallic phases and the possible formation of metallic alloys will be very similar to what was verified in the powder material that was used to perform the coating. In order to understand whether or not there is formation of metallic alloys, and to understand to what extent the synthesis procedure could contribute to the formation of these structures, XRD and TPR analyses were performed for selected powder catalysts, that recreate the synthesis procedure used for the macrostructured catalysts in powder. The obtained results are present in Fig. 3. Table 4 presents the values corresponding to the description of the diffraction peaks obtained for each of the samples analyzed by XRD. From the XRD patterns, present in Fig. 3 (A) and (B), all the Pd-Cu samples present a well defined diffraction peak around 40° corresponding to the Pd signal. The diffraction peaks gradually shift to slightly higher values of 2θ (as it is possible to see through the results present in Table 4) for the bimetallic catalysts, which suggests the formation of Pd-Cu alloys [59–61]. A narrower diffraction peak with larger magnitude was observed for the sample synthesized through co-impregnation (5 %Pd-2.5 %Cu/CNT(BM 2 h)) and for the staged impregnation samples without thermal treatment between each stage (5 %Pd/CNT(BM 2 h) + 2.5 %Cu). This shift is associated with the contraction of fcc crystalline lattices, which can be caused by the partial replacement of Pd atoms with smaller sized Cu atoms, being a sign of the formation of metal alloys [62,63]; the d-spacing values are representative of the distance between planes of atoms in the crystalline structure meaning that a decrease on this value is associated with the inclusion on Cu on the Pd sample matrix [64]. Cai et al. [65] showed in a previous work that there is a relationship between the formation of metal alloys and/or interaction between the two metals and the temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profiles obtained for these catalysts. Generally, the TPR profile obtained for each catalyst allows to draw conclusions regarding the interaction of the two metals on the support. It is thus possible to conclude that the thermal treatment, or lack of, in a staged impregnation methodology (5 %Pd/CNT(BM 2 h) + 2.5 %Cu and 5 %Pd/CNT(BM 2 h) + TT = 200 °C + 2.5 %Cu) results in different interactions between the two metallic phases of the material. For the 5 %Pd/CNT(BM 2 h) + 2.5 %Cu catalyst, the obtained profile suggests a greater interaction between Pd and Cu centers and, thus, a greater chance of forming metallic alloys. When a reductive thermal treatment is applied between the impregnation stages (5 %Pd/CNT(BM 2 h) + TT = 200 °C + 2.5 %Cu), a different profile was detected with the appearance of a inverted peak (for a temperature around 70 °C); this peak is attributed to the decomposition of PdHx indicating that Pd still exists in its element state (it follows that this peak is more evident for the TPR profile of the monometallic 5 %Pd/CNT(BM 2 h)) [65]. For the staged impregnation methodology, with a reductive thermal treatment between each stage, the distribution of the two metallic phases is not as homogeneous as in the case of 5 %Pd/CNT(BM 2 h) + 2.5 %Cu. Also, correlating these results with those obtained in the XRD analyses (Fig. 3 (A) and (B)), it is possible to conclude that 5 %Pd/CNT(BM 2 h) + 2.5 %Cu sample should present more metal alloys than 5 %Pd/CNT(BM 2 h) + TT = 200 °C + 2.5 %Cu sample; in the latter case, there may be a greater coverage of the previously impregnated and reduced Pd by the subsequently impregnated Cu, without formation of metallic alloys, as can be seen through the XRD patterns. A similar TPR profile was obtained for the co-impregnation sample (5 %Pd-2.5 %Cu/CNT(BM 2 h)); however, in this case, XRD results suggest the formation of Pd-Cu alloys. This way, a staged adsorption methodology shows to be an interesting methodology for the synthesis of bimetallic catalysts with higher Pd-Cu interaction; however, these closer interactions between the two metals may not necessarily be associated with the formation of metallic alloys and, therefore, may not contain the catalytic properties of these structures (as it happens for 5 %Pd/CNT(BM 2 h) + TT = 200 °C + 2.5 %Cu catalyst). Also, taking into account these results, it is expected that Pd-Cu metal alloys are inevitably present in catalysts synthesized by washcoating since these structures are already present in the bimetallic powder that was subsequently incorporated into the support. 3.2 Continuous experiments results To assess the catalytic performance of the synthesized macrostructured catalysts they were tested in the NO3 - catalytic reduction in a continuous catalytic system. The possible metal leaching was also studied for all the synthesized catalysts through ICP-OES analysis of an after reaction liquid sample and no metal leaching was detected during the catalytic experiments. The conversion results and corresponding selectivities to N2, NH4 + and NO2 -, for the bimetallic macrostrucutred catalysts synthesized through adsorption process are present in Fig. 4. In a first stage, a blank experiment (reaction without catalyst, not pictured) was performed and no NO3 - conversion was registered during this experiment. A relevant difference between the macrostructured catalysts synthesized through adsorption on carbon-coated WCP and CVD macrostructures was identified. CVD allowed a higher incorporation of carbon on the macrostructured catalysts providing, this way, a higher content of sites for the adsorption of the metallic nanoparticles. For the catalysts synthesized through co-adsorption from a solution with the two dissolved metals (WCP_550_[PdCu] and CVD_[PdCu]), ICP analyses allowed to conclude that the metal uptake was very similar for both catalysts, independent of the carbon coating methodology. However, NO3 - conversion results were substantially higher for CVD_[PdCu] catalysts (around 29 %). For both catalysts, a high NH4 + selectivity was recorded. This increase in NH4 + concentration, for the CVD supported catalysts, may be related to a greater dispersion and accessibility through the catalytic layer compared to WCP. Macrostructured bimetallic catalysts synthesized through a staged adsorption methodology (WCP_550_Pd_Cu, WCP_550_Pd_200_Cu and CVD_Pd_200_Cu) presented improved NO3 - conversion results compared with the ones where the incorporation of both metals was performed simultaneously (WCP_550_[PdCu] and CVD_[PdCu]). A macrostructured catalyst synthesized through the staged adsorption methodology, but without the application of a calcination/reduction thermal treatment between the incorporation of each metal, was also prepared (sample WCP_550_Pd_Cu). This catalyst showed a slight improvement on NO3 - conversion compared to WCP_550_[PdCu] catalyst (around 15 % vs 12 % nitrate conversion); however, the most significant improvement is related to the N2 selectivity that strongly increased (around 80 % vs 9 % selectivity to N2). When the same methodology was applied, with an extra step involving a calcination/reduction thermal treatment immediately after the incorporation of the first metal, NO3 - conversion significantly increased for both WCP_550_Pd_200_Cu and CVD_Pd_200_Cu catalysts (to around 24 % and 61 %, respectively). For the specific case of CVD_Pd_200_Cu a higher NO3 - conversion is associated with a higher NH4 + selectivity (around 56 %); however, there is an evident improvement in the conversion results for this catalyst when compared with the others supported on WCP coated structures. ICP-OES experiments (Section 3.1) showed that the macrostructured catalysts synthesized through staged adsorption presented a higher amount of metal than WCP_550_[PdCu] and CVD_[PdCu]. This, combined with an increased interaction of the two metallic phases (either by the formation of metal alloys or by the promotion of a higher contact between the two metals), must be one of the main reasons why these catalysts achieved a higher NO3 - conversion since there will be more available active centers for reaction. Also, the application of a calcination/reduction thermal treatment after palladium adsorption allows minimization of leaching in the following step regarding copper adsorption, contributing to a greater stability and a higher metal uptake. Previous studies concerning the influence of alloy formation on NO3 - catalytic reduction, and corresponding selectivity of the process, proved that bimetallic catalysts are more active on NO3 - conversion when a closer contact between the two metallic phases is promoted, but both species are not alloyed [42,66,67]. However, N2 selectivity of the process is enhanced by the presence of Pd-Cu alloys, as in the case of the staged adsorption catalysts. As mentioned before, XRD results reported a higher formation of metallic alloys for the sample WCP_550_Pd_Cu. The higher formation of these species justify the low activity for NO3 - conversion of this catalyst in comparison to what was recorded for WCP_550_Pd_200_Cu catalyst; the great activity of this last catalyst may be associated with a closer interaction between Pd and Cu. In another approach, bimetallic macrostructured catalysts synthesized through the direct incorporation of the pre-formed bimetallic powder catalyst (through washcoating procedure) were tested for their efficiency to reduce NO3 -. Fig. 5 shows the obtained results, regarding NO3 - conversion and the corresponding N2, NO2 - and NH4 + selectivities, achieved with these catalysts. As previously mentioned, applying a higher thermal treatment temperature leads to metal nanoparticles sintering which can strongly influence the NO3 - conversion efficiency. For the bimetallic macrostructured catalysts thermal treated at 550 °C ([PdCu]/WCP_550 sample), no NO3 - conversion was registered, meaning that the application of such high temperatures leads to catalyst deactivation. However, when the thermal treatment temperature was decreased to 350 °C a slight improvement was registered, achieving NO3 - conversions of around 8 % with a corresponding N2 selectivity of around 50 % ([PdCu]/WCP_350 sample). The deactivation after exposure to 550 °C is associated with metal nanoparticles sintering. This was previously detected through the TEM micrographs obtained for the [PdCu]/WCP_550 sample (Fig. 1) and it was previously reported that metal particle sintering strongly influences NO3 - conversion due to the formation of larger metal particles and/or alloys. Soares et al. [42] have studied the influence of calcination and reduction temperatures on the catalytic properties of Pd-Cu bimetallic catalysts supported on activated carbon in NO3 - catalytic reduction and the obtained results showed that, generally, the activity of the catalyst decreased with the increase of the calcination/reduction temperatures applied to the catalysts; also, for temperatures around 400 °C, NO3 - conversions were strongly compromised. For the specific case of the [PdCu]/WCP_350 sample the lower activity registered may be related to two different factors: in one hand, the application of a relatively high temperature that leads to metallic nanoparticles sintering, while on the other hand, the use of a thermal treatment temperature of 350 °C may not be sufficient to perform a complete TX100 removal and the remaining surfactant may be covering some of the catalyst active centers. As discussed before, the presence of the surfactant for the synthesis of this type of catalysts requires optimization of its removal from the catalysts surface so that it does not interfere during reaction and does not hide active sites. So, it is necessary to reach a good compromise between the surfactant removal and the preservation of the metallic phase structure. This way, a washing method, using an organic solvent solution of isopropanol and acetone, was adopted to perform the surfactant degradation without compromising the metal nanoparticles dimensions by application of higher thermal treatment temperatures [45]. [PdCu]/WCP_wash achieved the most interesting results in NO3 - conversions (around 17 % of conversion with a corresponding N2 selectivity of around 50 %), due to the integrity and availability of the active phase (as it is possible to see in Fig. 1 (F)). In this case, the macrostructured catalyst was not subjected to any kind of hard thermal treatment. Also, the adopted washing methodology allowed a complete surfactant decomposition proving to be an interesting methodology to be applied in this type of preparation when the main objective is the incorporation of metal-based catalysts in a macrostructured support through washcoating [45]. As discussed before, the application of a washing methodology with an organic solvent solution (IPA:ACN) promotes the migration of the metallic nanoparticles into the tubes, which may condition the process selectivity for N2 formation. Panić et al. [68], when studying the design of catalytic carbon nanotube-based reactor for water denitrification, reported that a lower NO3 - conversion was achieved over a Pd-Cu bimetallic catalyst with the active nanoparticles deposited inside the tubes. Also, these catalysts resulted in a higher NH4 + formation which may be associated with the higher mass transfer resistance of the ions inside the tubes, resulting in a higher contact time and favoring the conversion of NO2 - into NH4 + [69]. In a previous work, where 5 %Pd-2.5 %Cu/CNT(BM 2 h) powder catalyst was tested in batch reactions, it was possible to verify that the selectivity to N2, despite the high NO3 - conversion efficiency, was only slightly compromised [28]. This way, the mass transfer limitations of the ion inside the carbon nanotubes are the main responsible for leading to a greater NH4 + formation due to the promotion of a higher contact time and, this way, leading to a higher NO2 - hydrogenation to NH4 + [20,68]. To evaluate the stability of the catalysts over time long-run experiments (10 h experiment) were performed for the most active catalysts of each technique studied ([PdCu]/WCP_wash and WCP_550_Pd_200_Cu). Both catalysts remained stable and active during all the experiment run with a maximum conversion deviation of about 3 %. To understand how the different preparation methodologies used to synthesize macrostructured catalysts influence their activity for NO3 - reduction, some calculations regarding mol of NO3 - converted per mol of palladium present in the catalyst were calculated for a representative macrostructured catalyst of each preparation method. The calculation of this parameter will take into account each macrostructured catalyst and the different arrangements of both metals, depending on the synthesis procedure. The obtained values are present in Fig. 6. A higher value of the ratio moles of NO3 - converted per mol of Pd will be associated with less available Pd active centers during reaction. This is not directly associated with the presence of less Pd on the catalyst structure but rather with its availability to react with the compounds present in the solution during reaction. Thus, focusing on the macrostructured catalysts synthesized through adsorption of the metallic phase on the carbon support, it is possible to conclude that for the catalysts synthesized through staged adsorption (WCP_550_Pd_200_Cu and CVD_Pd_200_Cu) there is fewer Pd active centers available to participate on NO3 - conversion than in the case of the co-adsorption catalysts (WCP_550_[PdCu] and CVD_[PdCu]). These results are in agreement with those obtained during chemisorption experiments (Table 3), where the amount of H2 chemisorbed on Pd centers significantly decreases with the addition of Cu, and this difference is even more evident when the deposition process occurs in stages. However, the catalytic experiments performed with these catalysts showed that the staged adsorption methodology allowed to achieve more efficient conversions than the catalysts synthesized by co-adsorption. This fact could certainly be associated with the formation of Pd-Cu alloys or the promotion of higher interactions between both metals that strongly contribute to increasing the efficiency of the catalytic process. This was previously reported in studies involving catalytic hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde to cinnamyl alcohol, where the performance of metallic Pd-Ru alloys was superior to the registered for both monometallic catalysts, separately [70,71]. Similar results were obtained when using Pd-Au catalysts for NO2 - catalytic reduction [59]. Generally, NO3 - conversion depends on the capacity of NO3 - to chemisorb on Cu sites, to be converted to NO2 -, and the availability of H2 to perform the reaction [72]. After conversion to NO2 -, it will migrate to Pd active centers to be consequently converted to NH4 + or N2. Taking into account the mechanism of reaction, it is evident that the formation of metal alloys and/or promotion of metals proximity plays a key role in the conversion process. The proximity of both metals facilitates the migration of NO2 -, from Cu active sites, and spilled-over H2, from Pd active sites, between the active centers. Moreover, the formation of Pd-Cu alloys further facilitates hydrogen mobility as it is responsible for the decrease of the bond energy of H2 on Pd [55]. The application of a staged adsorption methodology may promote a higher interaction between the two metals since the deposition of Cu occurs on the support previously impregnated with Pd. This can lead to the formation of Pd-Cu alloys or adsorption of Cu on the Pd centers and, this way, promote a higher interaction of both metal centers that will certainly influence NO3 - conversion and selectivity [73]. However, when comparing the results obtained for WCP_550_[PdCu] and [PdCu]/WCP_wash, a higher ratio value was obtained for the catalyst synthesized through washcoating of the pre-formed material, meaning that fewer Pd centers (or, generally, less metal active centers) are available to participate in the catalytic reaction. ICP-OES experiments (previously discussed) performed for [PdCu]/WCP_wash catalyst showed that this catalyst presented higher concentrations of metal than the macrostructured catalysts synthesized through adsorption, which could be indicative of better catalytic performance; however, this was not the case as can be seen from the graphs present in Figs. 4 and 5. This way, different metal distributions through the coating layers may be related to these differences in the catalytic efficiencies. To evaluate the metal phase distribution through the carbon layers of the macrostructured catalysts SEM analyses were performed for a monolith section near the channels to analyze the different washcoating layers [74,75]. The obtained results are present in Fig. 7. Through the images obtained, it is possible to conclude that there are significant differences, regarding Pd distribution on the carbon layer of the catalysts, depending on the synthesis procedure used. The macrostructured catalysts synthesized through adsorption methodology (WCP_550_[PdCu]) present a less uniform distribution of the metallic phase (in this case Pd) through the carbon layers of the catalyst with a greater accumulation of the metallic phase in the outermost layers of the coating. On another hand, the washcoating approach resulted in a more homogeneous distribution of the metallic phase through the carbon layers of the catalyst since the incorporation of the metallic phase is through washcoating of the pre-formed monometallic material. A previous work, related to the synthesis of palladium monometallic catalysts through the application of different synthesis procedures (adsorption on the carbon coated support and washcoating of the pre-formed catalyst) showed that the distribution of the metallic centers through the coating layers played a key-role in the catalytic activity of the material [41]. Generally, it was possible to conclude that the most efficient results were obtained for the monometallic catalysts where the active metal phase was deposited closer to the surface of the carbon layers. Limits to H2 and ion species diffusion through the coating layers may be associated with this efficiency difference observed between different synthesis methodologies. The distribution of the metallic phase closer to the catalyst surface occurs when the adsorption method is used as the deposition process of the active metallic phase on the carbon coated structure; this way, the active phase of the catalysts will be more available to contact with H2 and NO3 - promoting a higher reaction rate. The opposite happens in the case of the structured catalysts synthesized through washcoating where the metal phase is more distributed throughout the carbon layers of the catalyst and the quantity of active centers readily available for reaction (in the outermost layers) is certainly lower than in the catalysts synthesized through adsorption of the metal in the carbon structure. Similar results were achieved during this work where the bimetallic catalysts synthesized through adsorption were the ones that present higher metal loadings and, also, more efficient catalytic results in terms of NO3 - conversion. 4 Conclusions The present work allowed to acquire new understandings related to the synthesis of macrostructured bimetallic catalysts and the catalytic phenomena, depending on the synthesis procedure, allowing a better understanding of the key factors to be considered for the design of efficient macrostructured bimetallic catalysts for NO3 - conversion while allowing to achieve a good selectivity to N2. The obtained results showed that adopting a staged adsorption methodology is a key-step to obtaining more active catalysts with enhanced N2 selectivity. The promotion of a greater interaction between the two metal phases, without necessarily forming metal alloys, is responsible for giving the catalyst a higher kinetic capacity resulting in catalysts with NO3 - conversions of around 24 % for WCP_550_Pd_200_Cu and 61 % for CVD_Pd_200_Cu, with N2 selectivities of 73 % and 40 %, respectively. The macrostructured catalysts synthesized through washcoating ([PdCu]/WCP_wash) showed a NO3 - conversion of around 17 % and a corresponding N2 selectivity of around 50 %, highlighting the washing methodology as an efficient method to remove the surfactant present on the catalyst structure while maintaining the catalyst integrity and avoiding metal nanoparticles sintering which impairs the catalyst performance. Also, the metal phase distribution through the coating layers presented itself as a decisive factor in achieving enhanced catalytic results that significantly varied depending on the methodologies chosen for the macrostructured catalysts synthesis. A less uniform distribution of the metallic phase through the coating layers with a higher accumulation of these species on the outermost layers proved to be the most advantageous form of metal distribution for the synthesis of more active catalysts since it promotes greater availability of the metal phase for the compounds to react while avoiding difficulties related to reagents/gas diffusion through the coating layers. coredata.dc:description: The development of macrostructured catalysts for remediation processes is a key step towards the sustainability of multi-phase environmental systems, such as the catalytic reduction of inorganic contaminants. The advances towards practical applications faces great challenges regarding the availability of active centers on catalysts surface. To improve the catalytic activity of macrostructured bimetallic catalysts, it is crucial to understand which are the properties that most influence the catalytic activity of materials deposited on macrostructured supports. This work presents a systematic study on the design of macrostructured bimetallic catalysts with enhanced catalytic activity and selectivity. These materials were tested for selective NO3 - conversion to N2. The adoption of different synthesis methodologies allowed a higher metal-metal interaction, which is an important property influencing the efficiency of the bimetallic catalyst. Metal phase distribution through coating layers proved to be a key-step for the synthesis of more active and N2 selective structured catalysts.
